description.text: I designed this part to hold two laser galvanometers in an XY arrangement for use in a DIY laser projector. The piece is designed for a particular galvanometer (it's here: http://www.ebay.com/itm/200791159832?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1497.l2649#ht_896wt_1327 ), but the SketchUp file is included to allow you to make your own modifications.

This shape is optimized for printing on a MakerBot Replicator - position it so the plate is on the build plate. With the new (Aug 12) acceleration firmware and Skeinforge 50, I'm able to print these in about an hour. Edit 08/27/2012: Sorry if you downloaded the earlier version! The mirror alignment wasn't right because my spatial reasoning skills are poor. I've updated the files and removed the erroneous versions, so everything you see here should be good to print! Also, there's a video of it running here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lYd84s4xrZg)

comments.text: Do you have any spec on the galvos you used? I just picked up a couple that look to be the same but do no have any info on them. The eBay link mentions a tech sheet but no longer available.
comments.author: idig3d

author: bgphipps

description.text:
This is (what I think to be) a complete set of all the printed parts you'll need to assemble your own Mendel90 Reprap variant.
The parts are all laid out to fit on a MakerBot Replicator build plate and have been cleaned up by cloud.netfabb.com, so they should be good to run through your favorite slicer and print.
To learn more about the awesome Mendel90 see nophead's page here: http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/12/mendel90.html

These are very long prints! Skeinforge47 seems to think each build plate will take about 9 hours. See Nophead's blog for build instructions: http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/12/mendel90.html And the RepRap wiki page here: http://reprap.org/wiki/Mendel90 I haven't printed/assembled these yet, so please let me know if you find any errors or omissions! (except one: I have intentionally omitted the "fan guard" part because it's so easily findable in the trash)

title: Funnel with sieve for espresso 58mm portafilter (redesigned)

description.text:
UPDATE: IT WORKS! (kind of). I redesigned it with a little rotating wiper that helps push the coffee through the sieve. I would still like to improve the usability. This is for sieving your espresso grinds into the portafilter of your espresso machine. I've pre-made an stl that fits in a 58mm portafilter (most machines). I will post an update when I have tested it. The .scad file is just a mix up of mesh http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27805
and funnel
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49597 So yeah, get rid of those ugly clumps and perfect your shot of espresso! http://youtu.be/Tb4iAySdqVY

description.text: I saw some people making mouthpieces for trumpet on here, so I decided to try it myself with a CKB 7E. It's really difficult to find one of these mouthpieces to purchase so hopefully this helps. It's one of my favorite mouthpieces as it allows me to hit higher notes while keeping tone quality, and the 3d printed version works pretty well considering it's plastic!

comments.text: Awesome! Glad to hear it's working well! What printer did you use to make it? I'm going to have to try making it and use the acetone vapor method to smooth it out. I think then it would work really well without all of the lines from the printer!
comments.author: slapthemonkey32

comments.text: I'm using a printer bot simple metal. And I have never heard of putting prints in acetone I may give it a try
comments.author: MitchKosso

comments.text: Well there are two methods, both very similar. The easier and safer one is the cold acetone method, where you take paper towels and put some acetone on them. Then drape them across the inside of a tupperware container or paint can and close it to let it sit for a couple hours. Also, this technique only works with ABS, so if it was printed with PLA, it won't work unfortunately. Here's a couple videos of it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=biLVyGDvisM and https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h2lm6FuaAWI
comments.author: slapthemonkey32

description.text: Here is a Buckyball with 540 carbon atoms.  It is a second look at thing:12675 - Buckyballs - Molecular models.  The 540 atom Buckyball shown in thing:12675 contains difficult to remove internal support material.  Built in external support was used for this version.  A 540 atom Buckyball without support is included as is the openSCAD code.

The supported version was printed on a Replicator using a raft and produced a fair print easily removed from the support.  
The support structure and the c540 Buckyball were calculated separately and combined with Mesh lab.

author: Gorgar

description.text: The attached OpenSCAD script allows you to create trip-let blocks: shapes whose projections along the x-, y-, and z-axes can be completely different. Probably the most famous trip-lets appear on the cover of Douglas Hofstadter's book GÃ¶del, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid.

Instructions on how to customize the trip-let produced can be found in the comments of trip-let.scad. The script is very basic. Most notably, it does not detect whether the created trip-let actually has the desired projections or even whether the block is in one piece. You will probably have to experiment with various rotation settings before you find a workable trip-let. A couple of example trip-lets from the script (including an approximation of one from the cover of GEB) have been attached in STL format. You'll need to scale and translate the model appropriately before printing.

author: jsc

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74307 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=74307

Using the following options: type_of_phone = first
print_endcaps = Yes

This is a derivative of jamesarm97's Bowden clamp for his Rostock. In making a Rostock this hot end is a different style with threaded top. It doesn't need mounting bolt tangs. This was rescaled for this particular Hot End. Thanks for the original jamesarm97.
Note: There is also another derivative on Thingiverse of a bowden tube mount for this type of use.

If you have a screw top HotEnd then;
1) Print the cap.
2) Put the bowden tube through the cap top.
3) wrap some ptfe tape (teflon) or other tape around the bowden tube near the end for a compression fit when the cap is installed. Remember to have the cap on first - Duh. Or you won't be able to put it on after you wrap tape on the tubing. In wrapping the tape I just wrapped the tape about 2-3 mm from the bowden tube end. I think I did 5 or 6 wraps. It needs to not slip through the cap top hole nor be too thick that you can't screw the cap on the hotend. I then cut the tape in half around the tube. This is because it was too wide and too much material to fit under the cap. I then removed half of the tape. Next, position the tube and put the cap down and screw on as straight as you can. You may hear some plastic fibers/threads cracking. That is OK. Check that the tube is secure by giving it a couple of tugs and print. Caution: I just built this and am not near having the printer work yet - So - your milage may vary. And the added compression collet is from jamesarm97. I'm not sure who may use this on this Hot End. It does not directly fit. Or if they will possibly drill out the cap or the Hot End screw top to accomodate this compression method over wrapping tape.

comments.text: The teflon tape worked for a while. I then used a nut threaded on the end of the tube for better grip. I've since changed to a J-Head with the now common push fitting for tubes.
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: Did it work? The teflon tape?
comments.author: Caldar

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

title: Desk Tray for WD My Passport Ultra hard drive

description.text: I have a backup drive on my monitor stand, a WD My Passport Ultra (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EAS89AG/), and it's a tidy little thing. I find myself stashing things on top of it, like a tube of lip balm, some SDcards, a Matchbox car, and a bunch of charms, and then having them roll or slide off any time I move the desk. So I thought I'd design a stand which can be slipped over the top of the drive (using it as its base, and thus hiding it), with a gap for the USB cable, and giving more storage by extending out to the sides. I added three SDcard slots on the side with thumb-slots to lift the cards out.

Needs raft and full supports to print.  
If you print one, please post an I Made One picture.

remixed_from.author: Ablapo
remixed_from.title: Balancing Spool Mount for Prusa Mendel

description.text:
This is a fortified version V2 of my Balancing Spool Mount. I removed the anti rotation part in the middle. Now I am using toothed washers to prevent a rotation.
The left and the right arm are printed from the same stl file.
You will get an angled spool position for more stability by the 180 rotation of these arms. Updated to Version 2 !

Keep the metal rods leading to the spool as short as possible. At the moment it is carrying a 2 kg weight. But use this mount at your own risk. Version 1.0 - "F_Spool_Mount"
Version 2.0 - "Balance Spool Mount V2" Added a picture of the weak spot of version 2.
My first model on Thingiverse!
